author: By Katie Benner
title: Barr Leaves a Legacy Defined by Trump
description: Though he sometimes departed from the president, the outgoing attorney general’s term was dominated by how he navigated the Russia investigation and other fraught issues.
content: WASHINGTON — Soon after he undercut President Trump’s baseless claims of widespread voter fraud in early December, Attorney General William P. Barr’s time atop the Justice Department hurtled to its end. The president and his allies attacked Mr. Barr in public and private, making clear that he should retract his assessment or spend the last weeks of the administration belittled and possibly fired in humiliating fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Before They Closed, Restaurants Opened Doors for Us
description: Ligaya Mishan counts the many ways she misses eating out, and the lessons it taught her about the world and its possibilities.
content: The last time I set foot inside a restaurant was Wednesday, March 11. I sat alone at a narrow counter in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and ate hot, gilded pupusas off a paper plate, spooning curtido — cabbage and carrots stung by chiles and vinegar — out of a communal jar. From where I live, the subway ride took me an hour and a half each way, longer than the meal itself, but it was worth it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: What the Vaccine Side Effects Feel Like, According to Those Who’ve Gotten It
description: Here is what some of the first Americans to be vaccinated against Covid-19 are saying about how they felt afterward, with some side effects but no second thoughts.
content: Two and a half hours after being injected with a Covid-19 vaccine, Dr. Taneisha Wilson was hit with the worst headache of her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie McGee and Lucy Tompkins
title: Video of Nashville Bombing Shows Shattered Glass and Confusion
description: Investigators are searching for a motive, with officials grappling with whether the bombing meets the legal definition of terrorism. A recorded message from a parked R.V. said “evacuate now.”
content: NASHVILLE — With the authorities in Nashville now confident they know who set off a powerful explosion in downtown on Christmas morning, their attention on Monday turned to answering what may prove a far more difficult question: Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Don’t Let the Pandemic Stop Your Shots
description: Even as older adults await the coronavirus vaccine, many are skipping the standard ones. That’s not wise, health experts say.
content: Peggy Stein, 68, a retired teacher in Berkeley, Calif., skipped a flu shot this year. Her reasoning: “How could I get the flu if I’m being so incredibly careful because of Covid?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Seahawks Defense Is an Asset Again in Division-Clinching Win
description: Seattle’s much-maligned defense held Los Angeles to field goals as the two N.F.C. West teams streak in opposite directions to end the regular season.
content: The corner of the end zone beckoned for Rams running back Darrell Henderson, who took a third-quarter handoff, rounded the edge and sprinted toward the pylon. Scurrying away from Seattle’s line, Henderson evaded one defender — but not the man who raced clear across the formation to drag him down from behind, 2 yards short of the goal line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Yang Presses Forward, Wiley Is Sidelined: Highlights From Mayor’s Race
description: Andrew Yang met with the Rev. Al Sharpton, and Maya Wiley is in quarantine. Yet another candidate joined those seeking to become New York City’s next mayor.
content: Few elected officials seem more eager than Mayor Bill de Blasio to put, as he phrased it, this “God-forsaken” year behind him. But 2020 was not without its lessons for this mayor and for those seeking to succeed him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Altered View of Sports After 2020
description: The coronavirus changed sports. But it also changed us. Will our connection as fans always be divided into a before, and an after?
content: It was all taken for granted, wasn’t it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Jackie Saccoccio, Painter of Explosive Abstraction, Dies at 56
description: She specialized in large canvases on which splashes of luminous color swirled and clashed. Her goal was to make her paintings seem as if they were moving.
content: Jackie Saccoccio, a painter known for explosive yet delicately structured, almost atmospheric abstract paintings that exploited paint’s fluidity in the tradition of Jackson Pollock, Paul Jenkins and Helen Frankenthaler, died on Dec. 4 in Manhattan. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: 7 Wonderful Non-Covid Things We Learned in 2020
description: Sleep more, procrastinate less and get better at money in 2021.
content: What a year! Yes, it was terrible and awful and no one felt good about it, but on the other hand, time is a human invention and everything bad about 2020 will continue straight into 2021, because the end-and-begin points of a new year are arbitrary and meaningless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: Which Developing Economies Will Rise After the Pandemic?
description: The crisis has created many obstacles to growth, but also some opportunities.
content: After 2000, globalization and surging commodity prices astronomically boosted economic growth among nations with emerging economies. Over the next decade their share of the global economy nearly doubled, growing to 35 percent. By 2007, 107 of the 110 developing economies featured in the Penn World Table were catching up to the United States in average income, helping millions to escape poverty. The celebratory mood was captured in a popular phrase: “The rise of the rest.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: For His Second Act, Nnamdi Asomugha Made Preparation His Byword
description: The former pro football player has pushed himself in acting classes, onstage and in films. His latest drama, “Sylvie’s Love,” also meant returning to an early passion: music.
content: The lead in a romance may seem like a prize for most actors, but the star of the new drama “Sylvie’s Love” had reservations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Turning the Page on the Year
description: If ever there were a new year that called for a new notebook, this would be it.
content: The empty pages of my notebooks mock me at this time of year, as they have done ever since I was a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Karen Cetinkaya
title: Stimulus Checks, Vaccines, Pardons: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: E.U. Sets in Motion a Plan to Vaccinate Nearly Half a Billion People
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 28, 2020
content: “It is not even for me, but it is the only way to stop the virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China clamps down on travel amid new cases.
content: Officials have been testing hundreds of thousands of people in Beijing and millions in the port city of Dalian, after the country recorded 42 locally transmitted coronavirus cases in the past week. The outbreak interrupted months of near-zero case numbers. Residents of Dalian have been advised not to leave the northern port city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
title: Refugees Come Under Fire as Old Foes Fight in Concert in Ethiopia
description: Forces from neighboring Eritrea have joined the war in northern Ethiopia, and have rampaged through refugee camps committing human rights violations, officials and witnesses say.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — As fighting raged across the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia last month, a group of soldiers arrived one day at Hitsats, a small hamlet ringed by scrubby hills that was home to a sprawling refugee camp of 25,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.4 Million Homes in California
description: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.
content: This property, which has horse stables and a riding rink, is a few miles from Old Santa Susana Stage Road, used in the 19th century by travelers from Southern California to San Francisco. The road is now part of a state park in the foothills of the Santa Susana Mountains and is popular with hikers and horseback riders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Video Shows Black 14-Year-Old Falsely Accused of Theft in a SoHo Hotel
description: A woman falsely accused the teenager of taking her phone in the video, which fueled concerns about racial profiling. It was shared by the teenager’s father, a prominent jazz musician.
content: On Saturday afternoon, Keyon Harrold, a prominent jazz musician, and his 14-year-old son walked into the lobby of the Arlo, a boutique hotel in SoHo where they were staying, when they were accosted by a woman they had never seen before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain will register those who choose not to get vaccinated, and will share the information with the E.U.
description: Spain plans to collect and share with other European Union nations information about residents who decide not to get vaccinated for Covid-19, the country’s health minister said on Monday. Spain’s health minister, Salvador Illa, stressed that vaccination would not be made compulsory, but, he said, a register would be set up that would include all the people who turned down the vaccine after being called up for vaccination by Spain’s public health service.
content: Spain plans to collect and share with other European Union nations information about residents who decide not to get vaccinated for Covid-19, the country’s health minister said on Monday. Spain’s health minister, Salvador Illa, stressed that vaccination would not be made compulsory, but, he said, a register would be set up that would include all the people who turned down the vaccine after being called up for vaccination by Spain’s public health service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Nets’ Spencer Dinwiddie Out Indefinitely With Torn A.C.L.
description: Dinwiddie, who started at guard alongside Kyrie Irving, hobbled off the court Sunday in the third quarter with what was initially called knee strain.
content: The Nets’ first loss of the season Sunday night at Charlotte has proved especially costly, with the team announcing on Monday that Spencer Dinwiddie, who has been starting at guard alongside Kyrie Irving, partially tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee and is out indefinitely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Lori Loughlin Released From Federal Prison
description: The actress has completed a two-month sentence for conspiring to pass her daughters off as rowers so they would be admitted to the University of Southern California.
content: The actress Lori Loughlin was released from federal prison in Dublin, Calif., on Monday, having completed a two-month sentence for conspiring to pass her daughters off as rowers so they would be admitted to the University of Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Democrats’ Georgia Hopes Rest on Jon Ossoff, 33. How Did He Get Here?
description: Some well-timed introductions and a knack for opportunity have helped Mr. Ossoff’s rise in Georgia politics. Now he is pursuing his most ambitious goal yet, a U.S. Senate seat.
content: Jon Ossoff was 16 years old when he wrote a letter to John Lewis, the Georgia congressman and civil rights pioneer, that led to a spot as a volunteer in Mr. Lewis’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel and Sarah Blesener
title: How the Pandemic Is Imperiling a Working-Class College
description: The coronavirus has hurt Indiana University of Pennsylvania, but its financial problems were planted years ago.
content: Rachel Foor’s grandparents are in their 70s, so when the pandemic hit, its stresses gave her such stomach pains that she could not eat or sleep. She worried she would infect them if she brought the coronavirus home from Indiana University of Pennsylvania, where she is a senior, or from Walmart, where she stocks milk and eggs to help pay tuition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Jimmy Carter Rock & Roll President’ and ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
description: A recent documentary about Jimmy Carter airs on CNN. And the 13th season of “RuPaul’s Drag Race” debuts on VH1.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 28-Jan. 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Adam Goldman and Jamie McGee
title: A Quiet Life, a Thunderous Death, and a Nightmare That Shook Nashville
description: DNA tests show that Anthony Warner blew himself up along with a stretch of downtown Nashville on Christmas morning.
content: NASHVILLE — Anthony Warner had a solitary job as an information technology specialist, stopping in to various offices to fix computers. He was 63. He was not married. His neighbors barely knew him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Knee Problems Prompt Roger Federer to Skip the Australian Open
description: The 20-time Grand Slam champion had two knee surgeries in 2020. He wants to come back, but it remains unclear when he will play.
content: As organizers finalized plans to move the Australian Open to February from its usual January start, the top 100 men and women in the world rushed to sign up, yearning to play a Grand Slam in a country with few cases of the coronavirus, even if it meant a two-week quarantine upon arrival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Vaccine, Brexit, Trump: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Murdoch’s New York Post Blasts President’s Fraud Claims
description: With a scathing front-page editorial, the Trump-friendly tabloid joined another of Rupert Murdoch’s papers, The Wall Street Journal, in attacking the president’s attempts to undo the election result.
content: “Give it up, Mr. President — for your sake and the nation’s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Benson
title: Watching Earth Burn
description: For 10 days in September, satellites in orbit sent tragic evidence of climate change’s destructive power.
content: I have a pastime, one that used to give me considerable pleasure, but lately it has morphed into a source of anxiety, even horror: earth-watching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: A Look at What’s in the Stimulus Package Trump Signed
description: The $900 billion package provides more relief beyond the $600 checks that have become the focus in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — The $900 billion stimulus bill that President Trump finally signed into law on Sunday evening goes well beyond providing the $600 checks that became a huge sticking point in getting the legislation across the finish line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Outside Trump’s Inner Circle, Odds Are Long for Getting Clemency
description: President Trump has doled out pardons to friends and fellow Republicans. Thousands of others without connections have largely been left out.
content: Nichole M. Forde, a federal inmate serving 27 years in prison for trafficking crack cocaine from Chicago to Cedar Rapids, Iowa, saw the list of politicians and presidential pals who were granted clemency last week and lamented: What about people like me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Soothing Anxiety and Stress: Advice From the Year in Well
description: Exercise, new news habits, even dipping your face into an icy plunge pool are among the steps you can take for a mellower new year.
content: For many of us, 2020 was an exceptionally stressful year, dominated by fears about the coronavirus pandemic. Even with the vaccine on the horizon, we’re likely to need some stress management strategies to carry us into 2021. There’s lots of advice in this guide by Tara Parker-Pope, How to Be Better at Stress. Stress doesn’t have to get you down, she writes: “Approach it the right way, and it won’t rule your life — it can even be good for you. Here are ways to deal with stress, reduce its harm and even use your daily stress to make you stronger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Strips Powerful Vatican Office of Its Financial Assets
description: A financial scandal involving the secretariat of state has given fresh impetus to Francis’ reform agenda.
content: ROME — Pope Francis has stripped the Vatican’s most powerful office of its significant financial assets, the Vatican said Monday, after dubious investments squandered millions of euros in church donations, sparking an embarrassing scandal and prompting an ongoing corruption investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Chinese Citizen Journalist Sentenced to 4 Years for Covid Reporting
description: Zhang Zhan, a former lawyer, is the first known person to be tried for challenging the Chinese government’s narrative about the coronavirus pandemic.
content: A Chinese court on Monday sentenced a citizen journalist who documented the early days of the coronavirus outbreak to four years in prison, sending a stark warning to those challenging the government’s official narrative of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Best Breakfast
description: Genevieve Ko has an ace recipe for sheet-pan bacon and eggs that’s sure to be a game-changer.
content: Good morning. We’re hurtling toward the end of the year now, a year that’s been like no other any of us has experienced, and I made a pizza and ate it with my daughter and walked the dog and got to thinking about how much better I hope 2021 will be for all of us and particularly for those who read this newsletter in search of a measure of hope and deliciousness against the torrent of dark news and difficult days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Making Friends,’ a Bitter Grab Bag of Grievances
description: Tom DeTrinis’s solo show is full of rage, but in a way that’s bizarrely out of touch with this overwhelmingly disastrous year.
content: If you met Tom DeTrinis at a party (remember parties?), you might find him perfectly agreeable, even fun. The truth, though, is that he wants to punch you in the face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy Turns to Flower Power to Help Spread Vaccine Message
description: The architect Stefano Boeri has designed primrose-themed pavilions where coronavirus shots will be given, but not everybody is thrilled with the idea.
content: ROME — This has been an ugly year for Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: With No Tickets to Sell, Arts Groups Appeal to Donors to Survive
description: Virtual cocktail parties have replaced black-tie galas as cultural institutions struggle to pay their operating costs.
content: One of the headliners of the New York Philharmonic’s fall gala last month was Leonard Bernstein, leading his old orchestra in the overture to “Candide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A State Skirmish Over N.C.A.A. Amateurism Rules Has Quickly Become a National Battle
description: Since California passed a law allowing college athletes to profit from their fame, the issue has broadened and moved to Capitol Hill.
content: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our original report on the introduction of a California bill that would allow college athletes to benefit financially from their fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Cheerleader’s Vulgar Message Prompts a First Amendment Showdown
description: A Pennsylvania school district has asked the Supreme Court to rule on whether students may be disciplined for what they say on social media.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a Saturday in the spring of 2017, and a ninth-grade student in Pennsylvania was having a bad day. She had just learned that she had failed to make the varsity cheerleading squad and would remain on junior varsity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Small Number of Covid Patients Develop Severe Psychotic Symptoms
description: Most had no history of mental illness and became psychotic weeks after contracting the virus. Cases are expected to remain rare but are being reported worldwide.
content: Almost immediately, Dr. Hisam Goueli could tell that the patient who came to his psychiatric hospital on Long Island this summer was unusual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret O'Mara
title: California May Lose Some of Its Stars. But Silicon Valley Is Forever.
description: The obituary for the state’s tech industry has been written before, and it will be rewritten again and again and again.
content: Is Texas the new Silicon Valley? This month Oracle said it was moving its headquarters to Austin after more than 40 years in California. Hewlett Packard Enterprise, descended from the Valley’s original garage start-up, is off to Houston. Elon Musk has moved to Texas, too, and has hinted that Tesla, the car company he co-founded and leads, may also relocate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy uses flowers to help spread a vaccine message.
description: This has been an ugly year for Italy.
content: This has been an ugly year for Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Relief Package Grows as Campaign Issue in Georgia Senate Races
description: The two Republicans tried to claim credit for bringing help to Georgians, despite President Trump’s initial waffling over whether to sign the bill. The Democrats said the $600 payments to Americans were too low.
content: The $900 billion pandemic relief package that President Trump belatedly signed Sunday night gained steam on Monday as an issue in the Georgia Senate runoffs, with the two Republican incumbents seeking to ride the tailwinds of the stimulus bill and claim credit for helping to bring aid to the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Saying Goodbye to the Knuckleball, and Its Master
description: Phil Niekro is the seventh member of the Baseball Hall of Fame to die this year. The pitch he perfected also appears to be lost.
content: They gather every year, except for this cruel one, in the village where they are immortal. The men on the stage in Cooperstown, N.Y., at the annual Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremonies, brought joy to millions. We look at them and see endless summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman
title: Trump Signs Pandemic Relief Bill After Unemployment Aid Lapses
description: After calling the measure a “disgrace,” President Trump unexpectedly signed the bill, extending expanded unemployment benefits and an eviction moratorium, and keeping the government open.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday abruptly signed a measure providing $900 billion in pandemic aid and funding the government through September, ending last-minute turmoil he himself had created over legislation that will offer an economic lifeline to millions of Americans and avert a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Austrian Lockdown Covers Schools and Stores, but Not Ski Hills
description: A sunny holiday weekend drew a crush of skiers to Austria’s slopes, with crowded lift lines and parking lots making a mockery of social distancing rules.
content: Most of their European neighbors can only dream of snow-covered slopes while they endure holiday lockdowns, but Austrians are jamming ski resort parking lots and lift lines, defying social distancing rules as they take to the runs of their alpine country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Britany Robinson
title: It’s Not That Hard to Buy Nothing
description: Some people re-evaluated their relationship to things in 2020. Here’s what they learned.
content: Elizabeth Chai decided she would not buy anything in 2020, with the exception of food, coffee, toiletries (if she ran out of something essential) and the occasional service like a haircut. She would resist the urge to add to her wardrobe or to buy anything material for her home. She would fix things or borrow them instead of purchasing new ones, and she would get rid of stuff she already had; 2,020 items sold, donated or tossed was her goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: The Year Inequality Became Less Visible, and More Visible Than Ever
description: Even as shared public spaces emptied out, the gap between the economically privileged and the precarious became impossible to ignore.
content: This year, many Americans left the places where it was still possible to encounter one another. White-collar workers stopped going downtown, past homeless encampments and to lunch counters with minimum-wage staff. The well-off stopped riding public transit, where in some cities they once sat alongside commuting students and custodial workers. Diners stopped eating in restaurants, where their tips formed the wages of the people who served them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: New York Bans Most Evictions as Tenants Struggle to Pay Rent
description: The Legislature, addressing hardship caused by the pandemic, convened an unusual special session between Christmas and New Year’s to pass the measure.
content: The New York Legislature on Monday overwhelmingly passed one of the most comprehensive anti-eviction laws in the nation, as the state contends with high levels of unemployment caused by a pandemic that has taken more than 330,000 lives nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Heather Cox Richardson Offers a Break From the Media Maelstrom. It’s Working.
description: She is the breakout star of the newsletter platform Substack, doing the opposite of most media as she calmly situates the news of the day in the long sweep of American history.
content: Last Wednesday, I broke the news to Heather Cox Richardson that she was the most successful individual author of a paid publication on the breakout newsletter platform Substack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Betty Campbell-Adams, Bronx Evangelist of Carrot Cake, Dies at 65
description: The bakery Ms. Campbell-Adams founded with her husband has won legions of fans all over the world for the Caribbean-infused delicacy that is its specialty.
content: Betty Campbell-Adams, who with her husband — and the help of his Caribbean grandmother’s secret carrot cake recipe — founded Lloyd’s Carrot Cake, a Bronx institution that has become internationally renowned for its New York delicacy, died on Dec. 11 in Mount Vernon, N.Y. She was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How a Small Bar Battled to Survive the Coronavirus: An Update
description: We chart the trials of a tavern in Oakland, Calif., that was thriving until the pandemic brought economic and emotional turmoil.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: The Girl Scouts Accuse the Boy Scouts of Unfair Competition in Trademark Dispute
description: The use of the terms “scouts” and “scouting” in the recruitment of girls is a focus of a legal and public relations feud between the organizations.
content: The recruiting pitches are strikingly familiar: Character-building and leadership opportunities for girls await in time-honored scouting programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Rosen
title: A New Theory About the Monolith: We’re the Aliens
description: A mysterious metal pillar in a desert would be interesting in any year. But something about 2020 has made one a global phenomenon.
content: The desert of southeastern Utah is a wilderness of flat-topped mesas, jutting buttes and plunging canyons. It is a fantastical landscape, the kind of scenery that pulls your thoughts toward things not quite of this earth. Indigenous people from the region have told stories of deities who formed the mountains by sweeping rocks through a hole in the heavens, and of warrior gods who stomped the topography into existence with their mighty footfalls. Other local legends hold that the desert is haunted by screaming ghosts or stalked by a phantom wolf. The area is known for U.F.O. sightings, and its arid terrain, dotted with crimson sandstone outcroppings, has often been likened to Mars. Since 2001, a group advocating the human settlement of Mars has maintained a research center outside a small town called Hanksville, where crews live for weekslong stretches to simulate habitation on the red planet. The desert is, literally, home to would-be Martians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: More Than 190,000 Ceiling Fans Are Recalled After Blades Detach
description: The flying blades can cause injury and damage property, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
content: More than 190,000 ceiling fans available through The Home Depot have been recalled after it was found that their blades could detach while spinning, causing injuries and property damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Essays Struggle With Big Ideas
description: “In the Land of the Cyclops” collects earnest essays about artists and photographers, “Madame Bovary,” Ingmar Bergman, Michel Houellebecq and more.
content: Randy Newman’s catalog includes a remarkable song, heard to best effect on his 2011 album “Live in London,” called “I’m Dead (But I Don’t Know It).” It’s about being an artist whose best work is thought to be in the rearview mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Fuller
title: A History of the Cheetah in ‘Wonder Woman’
description: This villain, played by Kristen Wiig in “Wonder Woman 1984,” has had a long, complicated relationship with her rival.
content: While the Cheetah may not be the most popular cat woman DC Comics has been responsible for, her high-profile appearance in the “Wonder Woman” sequel has a chance to earn her a whole new generation of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: Ring Out 2020 With Shots You’ll Actually Enjoy
description: These complex and composed shots thrive in the moment and are sure to brighten your evening.
content: At this point in 2020, we deserve a shot. But before you reach for the tequila and gird yourself for the next morning, adjust your definition of “shot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Did You Miss Out on Vacation This Year? You’re Not Alone
description: Employers are struggling to deal with the unused days that have piled up during the pandemic.
content: In a typical year, New York employees of the magazine publisher Condé Nast must use their vacation days before late December or lose them — a common policy across corporate America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 28, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 28, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 28, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Saudi Activist Who Fought for Women’s Right to Drive Is Sentenced to Prison
description: Loujain al-Hathloul, who was arrested just before the driving ban was lifted, was charged with undermining the kingdom in a case that supporters decried as a political persecution.
content: CAIRO — One of Saudi Arabia’s best-known prisoners, the women’s rights activist Loujain al-Hathloul, was sentenced on Monday to five years and eight months in prison, capping a two-and-a-half-year legal ordeal that rights groups and her supporters called punishment for her political advocacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For Television and Romance Novels, Love at Last?
description: The new Netflix series “Bridgerton” joins a tiny but growing handful of prestige shows adapted from mass-market romance books. What took so long?
content: Chris Van Dusen doesn’t describe himself as an avid romance reader. “I’ve dabbled,” he said in a recent interview. “I wouldn’t say that I have romance books lining my bookshelf.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Her Stomach Hurt Unbearably. Her Doctors Were Baffled.
description: Then she remembered a story from her mother.
content: The 45-year-old leaned forward in the car’s front seat, the seatbelt tight across her chest. She and her partner had driven to pick up some groceries, but now she was afraid to move, terrified of doing anything that might trigger the intense pain she was suffering. Her boyfriend looked at her, worried and frustrated. You have to go to the hospital, he told her. She had been in pain all morning, but each time he suggested they go to the E.R., she refused. Now she finally relented. He edged the car out into traffic and drove to nearby Cooley Dickinson hospital in Northampton, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The Most-Read Stories of 2020
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: What were the most-read stories in The New York Times this year? You may not be surprised to learn that two topics — the election and the pandemic — dominate the list, accounting for 90 of the top 100 entries. Here’s a selection of those stories, plus some other subjects that drew big reader interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Erdrich
title: Not Just Another Pipeline
description: The expansion of Enbridge’s Line 3 pipeline is a breathtaking betrayal of Minnesota’s Indigenous communities — and the environment.
content: PALISADE, Minn. — My daughter and I are walking along the fast-flowing stream of pure darkness that is the young Mississippi River. We are two hours north of Minneapolis, in Palisade, Minn., where people are gathering to oppose the Line 3 pipeline. Patches of snow crunch on pads of russet leaves as we near the zhaabondawaan, a sacred lodge along the river’s banks. It is here that Enbridge is due to horizontally drill a new pipeline crossing beneath the river. We enter the lodge. The peace, the sweetness, the clarity of the water is hard to bear. The brush and trees hardly muffle the roar of earth-moving and tree-felling equipment across the road. The pipeline is almost at the river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: An Intimate Send-Off to the Year of Being Together
description: Most of us will be spending New Year’s Eve with the same people we spent the entire pandemic with. Let’s celebrate our small social circles with some good food and delicious wine.
content: In the end, 2020 was the year of being together. We might as well go out the same way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Will Wright
title: Kentucky Is Hurting as Its Senators Limit or Oppose Federal Aid
description: Urban and rural fortunes diverge in the state, with the pandemic compounding troubles that predated it.
content: In Perry County, Ky., the local government is cutting back on garbage pickup. Magoffin County is laying off public safety workers. And in Floyd County, where food pantries are reporting that demand has tripled over the past month, officials are trying to figure out how to avoid cuts to a program distributing food to families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Connors
title: How Parade Underwear Took Over Instagram
description: Free underwear went a long way for this small business.
content: The tagged photo section on the Instagram page for Parade, an underwear start-up founded in fall 2019, shows a surfeit of images of young women modeling brightly colored briefs and bikinis. Many of them pose in studio apartments, stretched out on velvet couches and propped up on dressers. Some press against vinyl shower curtains, donning the neon underwear in mirror selfies. All of them look effortless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Howerton
title: I Hate the Mom That Covid Has Made Me
description: The pandemic has changed my relationship with my teens.
content: One recent Thursday, I sent my 14- and 15-year-old boys off to the skate park near our house. I’m a parent who values a childhood lived outdoors. To that end, I’ve been a fairly free-range mom with my four kids, but as they left for the park, I gave them a warning that still feels foreign, even eight months into this pandemic. “Leave your masks on!” They both gave a nod of agreement and were off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Risks of Using Steroids for Respiratory Infections
description: Doctors often prescribe them for sore throats and the common cold, even though evidence of benefit is sorely lacking.
content: “Steroid Shots and the Culture of Instant Gratification,” an editorial published Oct. 8 in JAMA Otolaryngology-Head & Neck Surgery online, highlights a chronic ailment in American medical care: a frequent failure to practice evidence-based medicine. Maybe I’ve been living under a rock, but I was surprised to learn that doctors often prescribe oral or injected corticosteroids for acute respiratory tract infections like sore throat, sinusitis, bronchitis and the common cold even though evidence of benefit is sorely lacking and risks of the drugs are widely known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carrie Thompson and Cheryle St. Onge
title: The 48 Mountains That Held My Grief
description: After my son Ben died by suicide, I turned to hiking. I found myself: broken, but braver.
content: On the first day of 2020, my anxiety roared as I approached the summit of Mount Pierce in northern New Hampshire. At about 4,300 feet elevation, the wind was picking up, the visibility dropping to near zero. I was about to turn around in defeat when I heard faint voices ahead of me: two women, zipping up their coats as I approached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Tony Rice, Bluegrass Innovator With a Guitar Pick, Dies at 69
description: The nimble king of flatpicking had enormous influence on a host of prominent musicians. And he could sing, too, until he could no longer.
content: Tony Rice, an immensely influential singer and guitarist in bluegrass and in the new acoustic music circles that grew up around it, died on Saturday at his home in Reidsville, N.C. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Catie Edmondson
title: Trump’s Veto Threat Did Little to Alter Stimulus Package
description: The president’s threat to scuttle a $900 billion relief package held workers in limbo, but did little to change the bill’s outcome.
content: WASHINGTON — As an exercise in raw presidential power, it was a flop. As a political tactic, it backfired. And as a coda to his final weeks in office, President Trump’s threat to veto a $900 billion Covid relief and government funding bill merely underscored his tumultuous tenure in the Oval Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: All Alone With a Microphone
description: In 2020, pop learned how much simple physical proximity affects music, and how to cope with isolation.
content: The last time I applauded live music with a roomful of strangers was sometime back in February. Applauding was an unremarkable reflex: the punctuation between one song and the next, a wordless expression of approval, clearing the air for the next organized vibrations. In decades of concertgoing I had often heard applause as a distraction, just noise that interrupted the musical experience. But during these long pandemic months I’ve realized that applause is really a bond: listeners communicating with performers, listeners communicating with one another and sometimes musicians applauding what they have just done together, with the audience as both witness and co-conspirator.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This Astrologer Has Some Things to Tell Kara Swisher
description: Chani Nicholas demystifies a $2.2 billion industry (and reads Kara’s birth chart).
content: Astrology has been around for thousands of years, so why are “Mercury in retrograde” memes and horoscopes still so popular in 2020?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: The Lasting Lessons of John Conway’s Game of Life
description: Fifty years on, the mathematician’s best known (and, to him, least favorite) creation confirms that “uncertainty is the only certainty.”
content: In March of 1970, Martin Gardner opened a letter jammed with ideas for his Mathematical Games column in Scientific American. Sent by John Horton Conway, then a mathematician at the University of Cambridge, the letter ran 12 pages, typed hunt-and-peck style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul McAdory
title: How My Pet Snake Taught Me to Really See
description: For most of us, snakes are as much symbol as animal. But I haven’t communed with a metaphor for all these years.
content: When prompted by a website’s security question or a nostalgic turn in conversation, I say my first best friend was a boy named Colby. We met at age 2 and share a birthday, Jan. 5, a coincidence that seemed meaningful so early in life, enough to base a friendship on. It is an easy story to tell. But it’s not the whole truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Night Lights
description: Even if you’re not afraid of the dark, you may want one of these.
content: If you’ve ever stubbed your toe while stumbling to the bathroom in the middle of the night, the value of a good night light is obvious — even if you’re no longer a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
title: For Covid-19 Vaccines, Some Are Too Rich — and Too Poor
description: Global inequality is shaping which countries get vaccines first. In South Africa, people’s best chance for vaccines anytime soon is to join an experimental trial.
content: CAPE TOWN — A few months from now, a factory in South Africa is expected to begin churning out a million doses of Covid-19 vaccine each day in the African country hardest-hit by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 6, 2021
description: How many workers are there in frontline and essential occupations? Who should get vaccinated first?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Judge Rejects Ghislaine Maxwell’s $28.5 Million Bail Proposal
description: The British socialite, charged with assisting Jeffrey Epstein in his abuse of girls, had called jail conditions “intolerable.” Prosecutors said she has her own shower, TV and computers.
content: Ghislaine Maxwell, the British socialite and longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein who is charged with contributing to his abuse of teenage girls more than two decades ago, was again denied bail by a federal judge on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: The Gospel of Hydrogen Power
description: Mike Strizki powers his house and cars with hydrogen he home-brews. He is using his retirement to evangelize for the planet-saving advantages of hydrogen batteries.
content: In December, the California Fuel Cell Partnership tallied 8,890 electric cars and 48 electric buses running on hydrogen batteries, which are refillable in minutes at any of 42 stations there. On the East Coast, the number of people who own and drive a hydrogen electric car is somewhat lower. In fact, there’s just one. His name is Mike Strizki. He is so devoted to hydrogen fuel-cell energy that he drives a Toyota Mirai even though it requires him to refine hydrogen fuel in his yard himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: The House voted to advance $2,000 stimulus checks demanded by Trump.
description: The House voted on Monday evening to increase the size of individual stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, endorsing a measure demanded by President Trump and daring Senate Republicans to either approve the heftier sum or defy the president, whose demands for bigger checks nearly scuttled the entire stimulus package.
content: The House voted on Monday evening to increase the size of individual stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, endorsing a measure demanded by President Trump and daring Senate Republicans to either approve the heftier sum or defy the president, whose demands for bigger checks nearly scuttled the entire stimulus package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaci Conry
title: Some of Jackie O.’s Favorite Fabrics are Back on the Market
description: In the late 1960s, Tillett Textiles teamed up with designers in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, for a historically significant collaboration. Now the prints are being reissued.
content: The party that introduced the Design Works of Bedford-Stuyvesant textile collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the fall of 1971 drew quite a crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Revisiting the Unseen Corners of the World
description: During a year with limited travel possibilities, our World Through a Lens series offered Times readers a weekly escape. Here are some of the highlights.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series to help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: H. Jack Geiger, Doctor Who Fought Social Ills, Dies at 95
description: He used medicine to take on poverty, racism and the threat of nuclear destruction. Two groups he helped start won Nobel Peace Prizes.
content: Dr. H. Jack Geiger, who ran away to Harlem as a teenager and emerged a lifelong civil rights activist, helping to bring medical care and services to impoverished regions and to start two antiwar doctors groups that shared in Nobel Peace Prizes, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Joseph Bachelder III, Engineer of the Golden Parachute, Dies at 88
description: As a lawyer he used computerized statistical analyses when negotiating chief executives’ exit packages, to demonstrate why they deserved a gilded send-off.
content: Joseph E. Bachelder III, a lawyer and compensation negotiator who standardized the so-called golden parachute, which guarantees that top executives of a company are generously rewarded if they are forced out in a takeover, died on Dec. 13 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering the Restaurants America Lost in 2020
description: This has been a harrowing year. From fine-dining trailblazers to longtime neighborhood favorites, we commemorate just some of the many places that had to close their doors forever.
content: This has been a harrowing year. From fine-dining trailblazers to longtime neighborhood favorites, we commemorate just some of the many places that had to close their doors forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: The Year in Spaceflight
description: It started with a literal bang.
content: It started with a literal bang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Rev. William Barber on Greed, Poverty and Evangelical Politics
description: “Jesus never charged a leper a co-pay!”
content: “Jesus never charged a leper a co-pay!”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.4 Million in California
description: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.
content: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Black Teenager Falsely Accused of Cellphone Theft in SoHo Hotel
description: A woman can be seen yelling at the 14-year-old in video captured at the Arlo Hotel in New York City on Saturday by his father, the jazz musician Keyon Harrold. Mr. Harrold said her phone was later found in an Uber.
content: A woman can be seen yelling at the 14-year-old in video captured at the Arlo Hotel in New York City on Saturday by his father, the jazz musician Keyon Harrold. Mr. Harrold said her phone was later found in an Uber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malachy Browne, Anjali Singhvi, Natalie Reneau and Drew Jordan
title: How the Police Killed Breonna Taylor
description: None of the police officers who raided Breonna Taylor’s home wore body cameras, impeding the public from a full understanding of what happened. The Times’s visual investigation team built a 3-D model of the scene and pieced together critical sequences of events to show how poor planning and shoddy police work led to a fatal outcome.
content: None of the police officers who raided Breonna Taylor’s home wore body cameras, impeding the public from a full understanding of what happened. The Times’s visual investigation team built a 3-D model of the scene and pieced together critical sequences of events to show how poor planning and shoddy police work led to a fatal outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: New York to Investigate Rise in Virus Positivity Rate
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that the state’s coronavirus positive test rate had surpassed 8 percent, the highest daily figure in months, but said there were anomalies in testing and reporting around the holidays.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that the state’s coronavirus positive test rate had surpassed 8 percent, the highest daily figure in months, but said there were anomalies in testing and reporting around the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Biden Calls Trump Administration’s Blocking the Transition Irresponsible
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Monday that his transition team faced “obstruction” from the political leadership at the Defense Department, after participating in a briefing with national security experts.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Monday that his transition team faced “obstruction” from the political leadership at the Defense Department, after participating in a briefing with national security experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Reviewing a Wild Year in Art With the ‘Culture Gabfest’
description: The co-hosts of Slate’s long-running and influential podcast discuss the “urgency” of art in a crisis and whether Meryl Streep should play Anthony Fauci.
content: This year was bittersweet for the culture consumer under lockdown. Some ways of experiencing art (reading, watching television, listening to podcasts) felt more necessary than ever, while the absence or degradation of others (going to the movies, or to the theater, or to a live music performance) left an agonizing void. The pandemic and subsequent crises of racial justice and democracy bled into all of it, posing new questions about meaning and merit that will linger long after the virus fades.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wrestling With Complicity in the Trump Administration
description: Readers, reacting to an Op-Ed by a former Justice Department lawyer about her ethical conflicts, offer both censure and sympathy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Delay in Signing the Covid Relief Bill
description: Readers express dismay at the tardiness, and exhaustion at a crisis averted. Also: How to foster bipartisanship.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Praying Together on Zoom: Yes, God Is Present
description: A pastor writes that Zoom services can “unite us during an unimaginably isolating time.” Another reader hopes that online synagogue services continue after the pandemic.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
